Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine. Here I am.
Feels like ages. You've been hard to find lately.
Verdun. There you are.
Shall I commend your perseverance or condemn your dereliction?

Fields.MenuText: Our course is set. The holds are full. The crew and the officers have it under control.
I don't have to defend my motives to you.
Which would you prefer?

Fields.DialogueText: Then give me an order.
Bon. Do not.
You would sooner run me aground than have me run this war on my preferences.
I can't say hello to a friend?
Non, you may. Pardonnez-moi, Capitaine. The demands of the forthcoming mission have kept me preoccupied.
The North Sea is certainly a hotter zone than the Black.
And more critical to the war effort.
I thought you'd forgiven Stalin his little fashion show.
Shoring up civilian morale has military import, however tangential. My prejudice was half-formed, but I will not renounce it.
You're a big-picture sort. I respect that.
Big pictures are drawn with a thousand small strokes, but not all are created equal.
Don't let Marseillaise hear you say that.
I wonder if my cousin can hear anything over her sermonizing. She'd do better to focus on the problems at hand before solving the rest of the world's.
Is that what's got you down here knitting?
... There's rain. The season grieves. Not all of the crew have taken to this art. But they need mittens.
Can't pull a trigger with frostbite.
Yes, you can.
... I've learned not to ask at this point.
Wise.
*ALARM*
En tout cas. We will catch up.
@BATTLE
Every time I think I've figured you out, you throw me something new.
I thought scones appropriate for tea.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
We are in British waters, after all.
Sentimental coincidence.
Yet delicious.
Ce n'est rien. A recipe is little more than a set of orders. There is room for interpretation in both.
... We're on a friendly ship, you know. You don't have to look around.
I'm paying attention to you. But this is a big room. Someone has to watch the points of ingress.

Fields.MenuText: There's nowhere safer than near you.
We've been at sea for days. We'd know if there were an assassin around.

Fields.DialogueText: Famous last words.
If that's so, I'm not doing my job.

Fields.MenuText: We could take turns.

Fields.DialogueText: We could not.
I know you for a capable capitaine. Talk. Snatch long moments from the grudging wars. Let me worry about the parameters of the situation.
Sure. It's not often I can get you to sit down and-
Parameters, Capitaine.
Right. I hate to bring my work with me, but this has been on my mind lately. I've been puzzling over these Morgana reports.
Puzzling how?
There have been reports of them firing on... well, each other. The Royal Navy has been able to observe infighting in relative safety.
And naturally they waited to pick up the pieces.
What would you have done?
Shattered them myself, of course.
Here's your chance. The tea's going to have to wait.
A moment snatched can be snatched back. We'll find an opportunity.
Doesn't it get hot in here?
I'm sure we could smother it with all these mittens.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Spoken like someone who has never been on fire.
If our crew have learned so little from our fire drills, I'd sooner burn with them.
I'm beginning to see why you prefer to let them do the talking.
My humans may share of themselves what they will, if it pleases them. I prefer not to leave... loose threads.

Fields.MenuText: Says the Belle to her human captain.
I can see that. You could stuff a breach with these.
Seamstresses are thorough that way.

Fields.DialogueText: Also not their purpose.
Call me what you will.
With complete confidence in her choice. Cherish it.
I haven't seen you work on one of your own projects lately.
Several factors conspire to make this the case. The mission, for one.
Never stopped you before.
I have never knitted on an industrial scale before. I'm adapting. It's fun. You should join me.
I might take you up on that if things slow down. You said "several?"
My own vanity, Capitaine. That unfortunate sailor I once threatened to keelhaul... suggested that I make myself a coat for the journey ahead.
Nothing wrong with that.
Non, Capitaine. Myself.
... As in, for your entire--
Which, as ludicrous a project as it would be, is possible. I am a Belle, after all. I am loath to spend my effort on lesser things.
No matter how crazy the greater things are.
My hands quiver with temptation if I so much as look at a sewing needle. Hence the knitting.
Quite the story you've cooked up to hide your concern for the crew's hands.
If such stories are true, I am certain I chose a capitaine who will not interfere in their telling.
Nor could I if I wanted to.
Indeed. To battle, then.
... Wait, that was a joke! Verdun!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Marin! Fall behind at your own peril!
Inspiring as ever.
Welcome to Hell.
Semi-Hell. Our job ought to be easier today.
Ah, brilliant. Have the Morganas unanimously scuttled themselves? Have we done with war at last?
The next best thing. There's a Treason squaring off with at least one other Morgana. We've been asked to intervene.
I sense in this a devil's bargain.
Welcome to Hell.
I don't like this, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: They can't all be ten-month slogs.
The smoke really ruins the view.
It was almost too easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Would that they could be.
Such morosity. One day it will not.
Victory freely given is worse than defeat.
But when else have we known Morganas to battle each other?
It's not unheard of. There have been reports of Morganas cannibalizing their derelict sisters, fighting over our own ships...
Derelicts, Capitaine. Starving scavengers. They are wolves devouring injured comrades. They do not conduct pitched battles.
Then what did we just break up?
An anomaly. We ought to snuff it out before it blossoms into a practice.
I don't know. A lot of the crew were quite glad to get the drop on them.
A lot of the crew would be quite glad to return to land and never sail again. They too shall be disappointed if they cling to that hope.
Has anyone ever told you that you can be a bit depressing?
Oui. I am also perceptive. Get me the after action reports for all reported cases of Morgana infighting in the area.
That's going to take a while.
As shall this war, I expect. I'll provide scones if you really need the motivation.
Find anything?
I suppose it's hard to find what you're looking for when you don't know what it looks like.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I'm not sure yet.
Harder still when one's capitaine is overly chatty. Have a scone.

Fields.MenuText: Only trying to help.
I should irk you more often.
I thought you'd at least be excited about the new gun.

Fields.DialogueText: Said the scorpion to the frog.
Ah, oui. The rifle.
Then come to me with observations.
If I am terse, Capitaine...
Don't worry. It's just the way you are.
Oui, but you are owed at least an insight. I... may have found something of interest.
Like the fact that these things don't end in the North Sea?
Précisément. The Irish Sea. The Western Approaches. The rifle grooves curl with flakes of rust. I don't know what your navies think they're doing.
Gathering information. This behavior is unusual.
Which is precisely why it ought to be stamped out before it engulfs the entire front.
You're a destroyer. You know the value of gathering intelligence before you make a move.
This is true. It could be nothing more than scavenging animals playing at imitation.
Grand maneuvers require grand responses, but we would be remiss in ordering a bombardment to clear a rat's nest.
Much as you'd like to.
Harshness is addictive, Capitaine. When you have a hammer, everything looks like a nail.
Especially if you are that hammer.
My, but you're in a romantic mood.
You Belles certainly have odd ideas of romance.
It is the way we are built.
You almost perked up there.
Have you ever switched your arm for a new one?
Can't say I have.
One day you will know the refreshing feeling of flexing a new, purpose-built limb.
I'll take your word for it. The technology isn't there for us yet.
May you live so long. I have been curious to perform such surgery.
Désolée. I've put you off your tea with my... theorycrafting.
Yours.
What does he owe you?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I've needed a pair of these for a while. Thanks, Verdun!
Do not mention it. Ever.
R-right. I owe you one.
Capitaine. You are adept at being in the right place at the right time.
Takes one to know one. That was a nice set of socks he walked away with.
Indeed.

Fields.MenuText: Knitting's addictive, isn't it?
Don't tell me you're going soft out here.
Do you think I could get a pair of those?

Fields.DialogueText: Like pinard to the poilu.
Bon. I will not tell you.
You are first among equals. Get in line.
It is as I feared, Capitaine. My largesse has consequences. People get curious. I hate dealing with curiosity.
First mittens, now socks. What next? Tea cozies?
Perhaps. I did say I would make you one.
You're serious, aren't you?
Always. It bears shocking similarities to my shooting practice, actually.
Something relaxing that lets you think?
All the world roars red and black. But watching something take shape or watching something explode, there is serenity. It takes little effort to act according to my nature.
More charitable than you let on?
Allergic to idleness. There is a difference.
It's keeping us all toasty in these waters. Keep up the good work.
You may consider it an investment in our crew.
That too.
... Indeed. Let us protect it.
And anyway, he's proven himself useful. Good hand with an extinguisher.
So why the secrecy?
Got a moment, Verdun?
I thought about what you said the other day.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Toujours.
The tea cozy will have to wait, Capitaine.
Not that. About Morganas... scavengers... acting according to your nature, all that. Then I did a little more reading on history. Recent history.
You found a common denominator?
That Morgana infighting in the Irish Sea and elsewhere out west. Remember the skirmishes between the Royal Navy and the Kriegsmarine? Early on, before the INPF.
I know a little of this. I've been focused on my stretch of the trenches, as it were.
September 3rd. U-30 sinks Athenia off of Rockall. September 5th, Bosnia goes down near Cape Ortegal. Triton screws up and downs Oxley on the 10th near Norway. Sound familiar?
These engagements... the Morganas have been sighted exchanging fire there.
They're fighting where we fought. Isn't that odd?
Hmm... They've been known to mimic our strategy and tactics. But they do so more or less immediately. They don't usually sit on their discoveries.

Fields.MenuText: But why?
So they're not just slugging it out.
They're doing their own research.

Fields.DialogueText: Why not?
Not without some design.
That too they have learned from us.
There are patterns to the Morganas' behavior, Capitaine. But they are mere stitches in some grander tapestry we've yet to unravel.
Sounds like your seamstressing is coming in handy.
Everything I do comes in handy. We Belles are not so unlike the Morganas in that way.
Aren't you?
Set a ship to catch a ship. We may not fully understand it, but war is like that. You must fight it and study it at the same time.
Time for a study break, then.
We will return to this. We may be on the cusp of something.
The more I look at the reports, the more disturbing they become.
That's a little chilling, coming from you.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I am a machine, not a monster. Anyone would be disturbed by what we're seeing.

Fields.MenuText: You're neither of those things.
What have we learned?
That's Morganas for you.

Fields.DialogueText: Revulsion is always worth examining.
The Morganas are learning, and in more ways than one.
Objective reality need not bow before sentiment.
Think on this, Capitaine. Why would the Morganas have to fight each other?
You'd think they'd have plenty of human targets.
Morale is no concern of theirs. They can always recoup their material losses.
You don't think they're conducting...
War games. Undisturbed by local strength.
And if they destroy each other, why would they need to be disturbed?
That is the first thing I expect Command to ask us. That is why we need to draw the pitch for the next game.
You lost me.
They are pacing out old battlefields, Capitaine. We need to give them a new one.
You're suggesting we fight a target of our choosing for the Morganas to learn from.
To prove they're actively studying us. We play a friendly, as the crew like to say.
And yet they can't get you to join them for football.
I have nothing to learn from the practice.
Except vocabulary.
If I thought I could decapitate a Morgana with a corner kick, I would schedule such drills from dawn to dusk.
We're coming up on some now. Your guns will have to do.
I'm still not sure how to feel about that hulk out there.
You humans use cadavers for medical studies. This is no different.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I'm glad I was able to convince Wallsend to part with one.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't strike you as... ghoulish?
That was generous of them.
Resourceful.

Fields.DialogueText: I wanted one of the Lion-classes from Cammell Laird, but they're dragging their feet on those.
If the Morganas want to use us for scrap, we will beat them to it.
Now we move it far enough from land to not disrupt Navy operations. Then we--
Shell the bejesus out of it.
I see you overheard the American crew I recruited to oversee the towing.
Problems, Capitaine?
It's silly.
Presque certainement. Give me your reasoned crisis of the soul.
Well, ever since you Belles awoke... I don't know. It doesn't seem right to use a ship like this.
Consider the Morganas. They devote their entire being to the war effort.
Because they know they'll come back.
And we will not. But the principle remains the same. The battle is won by the side that is absolutely determined to win.
If we are not willing to carve a victory from our very hides, the Morganas deserve it more.
I suppose I shouldn't be surprised. But it's hard to dismiss something... someone... when you're staring them in the face.
You are sentimental, Capitaine. I may not be able to cure this, but I can work around it. We complement each other.
If it helps, you may give the order to sink the hulk.
At least we haven't named her.
It.
... Right. Let's get this exercise going.
Quickly.
Taking a break from the mittens?
The crew--
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
Not those specifically. Tire!
*CRACK*
Are delighted. They have often told me so.
Especially the one you made the socks for.
Which? Tire!
*CRACK*
See? Keep it up and people will be fighting to serve aboard you.
Make no mistake, Capitaine. What I do is the correct exercise of my power as a Belle. A carpenter with a hundred hands would build a five-story building inside of an afternoon.
... What?
Morale. Equipment. Health. Time, resources, and skill should be bent toward the maintenance thereof. Tire!
*CRACK*
Not to mention the occasional tea cozy.
Not at all to mention it.

Fields.MenuText: If it makes you feel better, I can make it an order.

Fields.DialogueText: Do not abuse your grade de capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Take your time.
Admit it. You like them.

Fields.DialogueText: I am a Belle of my word. You will have it.
After a fashion.
Maybe I should join you. I've been out of my mind waiting for the spotter pilots' report on the exercise.
Do not be. Remember what I said about loose ends.
Don't leave them, I know. It's just--
Our pilots are committed to the task. If they fail, we enact contingencies. If they succeed, we act accordingly. One does not dwell but on a favored outcome. What is yours?
You don't have one?
Victory. There are paths enough to it.
We're certain they're converging on that location?
Angles of approach?
@BATTLE
Mortellement certain. Our planes report token Morgana forces forming up in the area.
Identical to ours.
Observe them in action. We'll compare their maneuvers against our exercise.
Let them be smashed in the unspeakable lists.
Why are the easy ones more unnerving?
As I said, Capitaine. Victory freely given is worse than defeat.
Incredible. They copied our movements right down to the hulk. That one didn't even move to return fire.
Non, she did not. But the one that did fire sank her target quicker than we did.

Fields.MenuText: It could be a coincidence. We can't jump at shadows.
Lucky shot.
They're learning.

Fields.DialogueText: Shadows need to be cast.
On a stationary target, with no munitions to catch. Don't insult my intelligence.
And quickly.
So we've replicated the pattern. Now we need to forward it to Command.
I still harbor concerns, Capitaine.
Go on.
I have expressed displeasure and even contempt for human practices and perceptions.
Frequently.
But the Morganas are a global threat. They mobilize your navies as nothing before them. I refuse to believe we are the only ones to see this.
Someone has to be the first.
This is an ongoing strategy from an otherwise tactical enemy. We would have heard about this by now.
You're not the first Belle to notice Morgana adaptation and strategy. Perhaps Command are playing it close to the chest. The enemy have noticed us noticing before.
... C'est vrai. I will think on this.
How goes the appeal?
I'm on the third draft since this morning. I'm trying to figure out how exactly to pitch this.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Oblivion lies upon navies and kings. We surmount the brink of utter destruction.
Something a little less apocalyptic.
At what point during an apocalypse does one name it thus? These Morgana war games must be treated with the gravest severity.

Fields.MenuText: There's a language to these things, Verdun.
Looks like I'll need a fourth draft.
Maybe I should have you write this.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure Command appreciate the filter they have in you.
Correspondence is as irretrievable as a bullet.
Words can obfuscate as much as illuminate.
And how about you? Keeping the crew in socks?
Keeping myself in evening wear.
... As in right now? Under your--
Do not debase yourself, Captaine. I refer to the formal dress I have neglected.
The purple number, right? I think I saw that the last time I visited your quarters.
I thought I might benefit from some flair. Mademoiselle Vampire's cape was a fine reference for the shawl.
We all have to make time for ourselves now and again.
The argument could be made that this is as much practice as my shooting.
It could be.
Oui.
Something else on your mind?
Confidentiality. I'm wondering how covertly I might write to Southampton about this.
Swapping sewing techniques?
I've heard she's integrated armor into some of her designs. Is it really so simple as a thicker stitch? Is interfacing involved? And what of the weight? I suppose that last wouldn't--
I think I needed this, Verdun. Thanks.
Needed what?
Later. Let's get out there.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Were we expecting--
Never mind what we were expecting. Aux armes!
That was a rough one.
This is nothing like what we faced in the Black Sea.
It's nothing like what we faced when we arrived here in the North Sea.
Perhaps that is the problem. The coasts have been quieter than I anticipated they would be.
Things are quiet, all right. They were right on top of us before we knew what was happening.
I am not easily snuck up on, Capitaine. And the Morganas are not the subtlest of enemies.

Fields.MenuText: Sedition and Sabotage make an effort.
We won't let one slip again.
That's just what they want us to think.

Fields.DialogueText: That is Paranoia you're thinking of.
We did not let this one slip. We are still alive.
We are lucky that they insist on acting according to those silly names of theirs.
That response from Command needs to hurry up and get here. They need to recognize that the Morganas are getting stronger, and quickly.
I am not looking forward to their response as much as you are.
You don't think they'll take it seriously?
I am certain they will not recognize the gravity of the situation.
Aren't you the one who told me not to dwell on things?
I am not dwelling on this, Capitaine. I am always prepared to take matters into my own hands. You must be as well.
Prepared to take matters into my own hands?
If you'd prefer I didn't. Let us leave it at that.
We have our response from Command, Capitaine.
Open it up. What's it say?
@BATTLE
... Merde. I hate when I am right. Here.
Hmm. "No immediate need to intervene... priority remains with active Morgana operations concerning civilian and military targets..." Damn.
After we've proven the Morganas to have learned from us before. After we've proven that they're actively teaching themselves. They're just going to let them fight it out.
What did you expect?
Well, I suppose nothing more. If you look at it from their perspective, there's only so much force we can engage with. Why fight an enemy while it's fighting itself?
Ambition must be met with ambition, Capitaine. The Morganas emerge stronger from every battle. If they are conducting their own, and across and entire theater...

Fields.MenuText: There's one thing I still don't get. Why is this different from them fighting us?
They'll run through all the scenarios in no time.
It isn't all gloom and doom. See the extra munitions they pledged us?

Fields.DialogueText: Superbe. Throwing tactics at a problem of strategy.
Or enough that we'll be hopelessly behind.
Coordination, Capitaine.
It's one thing to strike down disparate Morganas during their several pursuits. It's another when they're all bent on the same one.
Whatever fell intelligence directs them... it is taking notes. Learning. Educating, on a scale we've yet to comprehend.
Our orders are to engage any and all on a course for human targets. It's out of our hands.
Then we must seize it.
Command can only fight the war they can see, Verdun. We can't go against direct orders.
Fools made brazen by conceit. They will see it and issue new ones accordingly.
See what?
See to the battle at hand.
If they're hitting us smarter, we hit them harder, right? That should solve things at least in the short term.
Verdun, what's this I hear about a discipline problem?
Our crew don't have a discipline problem. You've made sure of that.
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
Ah, you saw the notice I posted in the mess hall. Tire!
*CRACK*
Have I, Capitaine?
It took us a while to come to an understanding about it.
Problems must be dealt with before they become problematic. Tire!
*CRACK*
Even so, there's no reason to give anyone time in the brig for messing up a salute. And this pledge of allegiance... lashes? Really?
Begins tomorrow, Capitaine. If the Morganas are learning from something as complex as our maneuvers, imagine what they might learn from the actions of an individual.

Fields.MenuText: How to salute incorrectly?

Fields.DialogueText: Among other things.

Fields.MenuText: There's no need to be paranoid.
How will more draconian measures help?

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr que non. I waited until a moment of crisis to do this.
How will they not?
Uniformity, Capitaine. Cohesion. If the Morganas are gaining in strength without facing us in battle, we must take the battle to them.
And if they are learning from us, we must be more united than ever in our purpose. I will do whatever is necessary to ensure this.
We've talked about this before, Verdun. I can't run this ship like a penal vessel.
They wear their freedom with a careless pride, Capitaine. Tire!
It is high time I restored some care.
Hmm. A general withdrawal?
Not from the North Sea altogether. But the Morganas have coordinated just northeast of the Shetlands, and in larger formations than any we've seen. Command don't want us to meet this head on.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
What did I just hear you say?
Where is the redoubt?
South of the 58th. We're to--
Capitaine, with respect, this is madness.

Fields.MenuText: You're not usually one to interrupt me.
You'll go along with it.
What's mad about it?

Fields.DialogueText: Under protest.
You are not usually one to concede defeat before the battle has begun.
A preemptive retreat? Have you forgotten who you're talking to?
I need hardly remind you that the Morganas' coordination was only possible due to their unchecked war games in the region.
Now, hold on. We still don't know that that's the only cause.
C'est un facteur! If we hadn't left them to their own devices, they would not be bearing down on us in such grand fashion! Command must ask advice of our experience!
There's nothing we can do for it now.
Faux. We can accelerate my cohesion measures.
Is that what you call demanding a pledge of allegiance from the crew?
For all their flaws, the Americans are familiar with the concept.
To their country, Verdun. Not to their ships.
I am pledged to you. You do not accept their unswerving loyalty?
Not if it's backed by imprisonment and flogging. I want that notice in the mess hall taken down.
Grand maneuvers require grand responses, Capitaine. If Command are unwilling to order one, I will have to provide my own. The crew have never been more vigilant.
They've never been more terrified!
They know what horrors they face from the Morganas. The worst I could do is execute someone.
You won't. That's an order.
Oui, Capitaine.
Your shoulders hold the sky suspended! Do not allow it to fall!
@BATTLE
Well done, everyone. Notify Command we've--
Marin! Ca c'était quoi?
Ma'am, I swear, I was--
Thrice you took aim, and thrice your fire lagged our target. Explain.
Well, that is--
A pattern of cowardice. Non, sabotage! One way or another, you shall serve as an example!
Gah!
*THUD*
Verdun! Stand down!
Capitaine, with your permission, I shall discipline the sluggard myself. No crew of mine will falter before an implacable enemy.

Fields.MenuText: He's done nothing wrong. Take your foot off and help him up.
As you were, sailor.
Let him go. I'll talk with him.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, I must insist on applying the proper force.
This is not over.
You heard the capitaine. Take my hand or remain where you are.
What's gotten into you?
What's gotten into you, Capitaine? Will you brook this dereliction?
I never thought I'd have to say this, but report to the brig. I'll be along after I've finished my report. With annotations.
You would imprison me aboard my own vessel?
You did that to yourself the moment you chose me. Follow through.
Oui, Capitaine. As you command.
When I send you to the brig, I expect you to stay there.
Then explain the evening dress you're touching up.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I never left.
I moved it to the brig the day before you aided and abetted my incompetent gunner.
You... what? You planned for this?
I expected a reprimand, but planned for imprisonment just in case you proved especially squeamish.
What's she playing at?
Command will see all they need to see once their man has come to the front. I'll see you on the bridge.
... You're not even interested?
That is all I needed to know.
They're sending an admiral out to observe--
In what capacity?
Why wouldn't I?
You've involved Command?
I know I can't keep you here during battle. But at all other times, you're confined to your quarters while Command figure out what to do with you.
You're getting out of... no. Verdun, you're not out of control. That's not possible. But I can't have you terrorizing my crew.
The Morganas subjugate the very will of theirs. Absolute obedience and even fear are the next best thing in times of desperation.
War makes weapons of us all. I will maintain them as such.

Fields.MenuText: Why couldn't I get one of those Belles that treats their crew like people?
Mercy is what makes us human.
You need a vacation.

Fields.DialogueText: I am not human.
I will take one when I am scrapped or sunk.
How is it out there?
As bad as anything we've seen since the start. No matter where we turn, it's like the Morganas have prepared for us. They're acting in ways we never thought...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Tu ne dis pas.
You're... knitting?
I never stopped. I noticed some of the crew's socks were getting ragged.
How many socks does it take to get back in the good graces of someone you stepped on?
Think on the battle of the Chemin des Dames. General Pétain shot some men for mutiny even as he bettered their rations and pay.

Fields.MenuText: You're not Pétain.
That's not a number.
Cold comfort.

Fields.DialogueText: Astute.
Dieu merci.
You do so much for the crew. I don't know how you can do so much to them.
The collapse of the Western Front would have been colder.
It takes little effort to act according to my nature.
This again? Verdun, you're more than just a weapon.
Correct. I am a soldier, and one uniquely suited to the challenge we face.
This from the Belle who masterminded the Morgana fashion show back east.
It, like me, was as you humans made it. And it, like me, was fit for its time and place.
Vanity must be the first casualty in war. I am not in this to be liked. I am not in this to be friendly. You seem to believe I do not care about my reputation. I have embraced it.
We'll see what the admiral has to say.
Bon.
I'm glad you made it here safely, Admiral.

Fields.MenuText: As her superior, I take full responsibility for her actions.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
Felt almost like peacetime. Your reputation precedes you. As does your Belle's.

Fields.MenuText: She awaits your judgment.
Whatever happens, we need her out here.

Fields.DialogueText: I commend your commitment to your rank. But the Belles are a... special case.
She doesn't resist. She accepts the consequences, at least.
I recognize that. That's precisely what makes this case so difficult.
Some of us are still opposed in principle to the idea of ships disciplining their sailors, to say nothing of her approach.
Are you?
It's the approach that concerns me more. Give a Belle enough power and she'll find reasons to use it.
Command have fielded concerns in that direction; mostly Japanese, but it's been seen everywhere.
Well, I'm sure you'll find that her performance hasn't suffered.
Good. Those blasted Morganas have been giving us pure hell...
Good lord. Where did they learn to do that?
From us. And... from each other.
Eh?
You've read the dispatches about their war games, I take it?
In passing. I'd thought it a coincidence. But to see the results with my own two eyes...
Amiral.
At ease, Verdun. Explain yourself.
I anticipated a wavering of morale in the face of refined Morgana doctrine. I sought to curb it swiftly and proactively.
With corporal punishment. That's no longer the way of things, as I'm sure you know.
With respect, Amiral, the world is no longer as it once was. I do not regret it.
That may be. Continue to defer to your captain's judgment. Command will exercise their own. About you... and the situation at large.
Oui, Amiral. Merci.
You never even blinked when you addressed the Admiral. I'll give you credit for audacity, Verdun.
You won't be able to use that excuse for much longer.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
There is none in explaining oneself honestly to a superior officer.
Whatever happens to me, it will have to wait for after the North Sea is secured.
With full understanding of what's at stake.
To defeat our valiant foe and all her deadly tools is no excuse. It is a priority.

Fields.MenuText: ... Verdun, what are you up to?
Could have fooled me.

Fields.DialogueText: Sans aucun doute.
War.
Well, credit where it's due. You've really gotten caught up on your sewing.
Perhaps that was my plan all along.
You'd beat a man into the deck for a few extra hours on an evening dress?
It depends on the dress and it depends on the man.
All right, now I know you're up to something.
Do you? I would do my best not to get captured, then. The Morganas would have much to learn from you.
Flattery won't get you out of confinement.
What flattery?
As if I would need it.

Fields.MenuText: The Admiral's left an observer to keep an eye on you.

Fields.DialogueText: An extra pair of hands? I ought to scare the INPF more often.
His contract is extremely specific, Verdun. No putting him in the boiler room.
I work down there from time to time. He is here to observe me. I will not dissuade him from joining in if his curiosity gets the better of him.
Don't coerce him.
As you command.
Damn it. They just keep coming.
How do you figure?
Bof. They are on the brink of collapse.
Because they just keep coming.
Tactics?
Tactics. Rather, the lack thereof. These are headlong charges as not seen since the war's beginning.

Fields.MenuText: So all we need to do is wound them.
They're getting worse?
It could be a ruse.

Fields.DialogueText: And leave them to be eaten by their sisters.
We're making them worse.
Everything could be a ruse, Capitaine. We meet ruses with fire.
They have mounted sieges, but we've never seen such a sustained offensive before. Perhaps we are simply burning out their reserves and their expertise with it.
Can that happen?
To oversimplify a great deal, that is how the Great War ended.
Well, we've come this far. There's no turning back now.
You have taken the crew this far. Perhaps I underestimated you.
You're the Belle.
Confined to quarters except for battle. Discipline has not suffered under your sole command. Morale is intact.
Higher, if anything.
It sets the brain awhirl.
All part of the plan, eh?
The war effort precludes an answer for the time being.
@BATTLE
You win.
Now that the immediate threat is over, Command have reevaluated our assessment of the Morgana war games. Any forces in the vicinity are to interrupt them with all speed.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I win?
There's more.
... Yes. You've been indefinitely stripped of your disciplinary authority over the crew.
Tant pis. I leave it in your capable hands.
Do not make me regret it.

Fields.MenuText: Well, thank you.
This was your plan all along, wasn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: I have been waiting for the day I could respond in the affirmative.
The way you handled the war games. All you needed to do was--
We did ask, Capitaine. We asked, and we were ignored by a command structure that is ruled by fear.
So afraid of these witches that they would rather watch them destroy each other than risk their own skin, even if it's all part of the enemy's plan.
The Royal Navy considers itself renowned in an ancient cause. So content with their supremacy that it has become self-evident.
Mademoiselle Belfast exposed as much with the Morganas' nefarious offer of detente. Bulldog, with her mad dash back from the Baltic to save an unsuspecting London. They--
So all this... was just to get their attention?
They were too far from the front lines to see the next phase of this war taking shape.
Those new rules... You sacrificed yourself to save us.
Non, non, non! We Belles are not saviors! We do not take your death for ours. We are an example!
I do nothing but my duty, Capitaine. When will you do yours? Or must I make a sharper point next time?
You've made it.
Have I?
We'll find out once the waves are clear.

Fields.MenuText: Recruitment's up, surprisingly. Maybe people got curious.

Fields.DialogueText: That has its uses. Any standouts?
Need a war artist? It might help your reputation.
Hmm. Can I keep him honest?
Within reason. We don't want to scare people away.
There will always be people with nothing to lose. I give them something to fight for.
I saw you apologizing to that sailor.

Fields.MenuText: That's a fine way to describe striking someone down.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
Non. I offered an explanation. He is free to think of me how he wishes to.

Fields.MenuText: You're incorrigible.
I doubt it would make a difference anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: It is as it was.
Well, word's spreading. You're not the first Belle to be harsh with her crew. Given your record, Command is prepared to view this as a lapse in judgment.
I certainly hope so.
You would be surprised.
Perhaps the crew will as well, in time.
And after such piteous platitudes of pain. You would be surprised at what - and who - humans are willing to rehabilitate in times of crisis.
I won't argue with you there.
And when this happens again?
Not when, Verdun. If. Command is going to take reports of Morgana organization and intelligence more seriously from now on.
Oaths are worthless unless backed by flesh.
Why else would we be in this line of work?
Going to the front is one thing. Doing your duty once there is another. Commanding in safety, another still.
Not all are born fighters for their time. More's the pity that they learn this fighting.
That's the way things are, as tragic as it is.
Then mark my words, Capitaine. We will be having this conversation again.
Verdun, I--
Weapons must undo weapons and force must undo force, Capitaine. Or did you believe that angels would descend to save you from demons? That the end of the world would be a fine place to make friends?
Consider the knitting a sticking point.
... I thought he could use a new--
Quilt?
You know the value of morale.
You too, Verdun. More than you let on.
Now, come on. Don't make us court-martial you.
Jamais.
There's one thing I still don't get.
I get the need for operational security. Why couldn't you at least tell me?
We will look into making one. The Fleet has steel enough.
Only one? Pass me that pincushion.
You know the Morganas for scavengers. I could not risk your capture, for I could not risk the integrity of my plan.

Fields.MenuText: And if you were taken?
I love you too, Verdun.
Well, thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: Ask yourself this, Capitaine. What does it say about Command's priorities that I had to invent a villain to draw their attention to the true evil?
That is an argument against making plans, not in favor of sharing them.
Quel charme.
Think nothing of it. I would never let them take you.
Probably that they expect better of you.
And they do not expect worse of the Morganas?
We focus on what we can control.
And a terrible beauty is born from that decision.
You're never going to let this go, are you?
I am a seamstress, Capitaine. I have told you how loose ends catch.
Et... voila.
A tea cozy! Thank you, Verdun.
I am a Belle of my word.
Now I just need a teapot to go with it. We've been using yours all this time.
